Featured

At Madison Square Garden, the Fans Are Still the Biggest Losers

While Dolan still rules supreme, Knicks fans are spectators to a grim and depressing reality of stubbornness and failure

Here it is, another grisly end to an unbearably embarrassing season. Like always, some New York Knicks fans will say that through it all “they fought the good fight.” Others will look to the future, the draft, free agency, and the rise of Kristaps Porzingis for hope. The organization will go through the motions of an exit meeting with players.

And, lastly, but most importantly, the fans will be the biggest losers at the end of the season, like every season.

The New York Knicks have been losing since forever. The 2012–13 season, when Carmelo Anthony led the team to 54 wins, was the last time the Knicks sniffed the playoffs. Near the end of the subsequent season was when they hired Phil Jackson as the President of Basketball Operations. Since he took office that March, the Knicks have a record of 90–170 (.346). This number may seem biased since there’s not much anyone can do on their first day on the job. So, let’s eliminate the end of his first season. Also, if the tank season was by design, that should be eliminated as well since trusting the process is imperative to success. That leaves Jackson with two full seasons of discretionary power. Crunch the numbers and that comes out to unbiased 62–100 in wins-losses. That’s a .382 in win percentage.

Obviously, the Knicks are losing, but according to Forbes they’re still the most valuable franchise in the NBA. Even more, they’re no. 7 in the world, just behind the defending Super Bowl champs. However, the parallels don’t end there. Both teams were purchased in the mid-1990s, and both the Knicks and Patriots values have exploded since then. The buck stops there when fans and the brands are considered. The Knicks brand is estimated to be worth $505 million while the Patriots brand pushes $431 million. Although the numbers are a bit outdated, Forbes ranked the Knicks fifth in merchandise sales and had three players in the top 15 of jersey sales from October through December of 2016. Numbers like that would indicate a prospering team, but unfortunately, that bottom line indication is incorrect since the Knicks record is a signal of success. If the Knicks could generate that kind of revenue losing, and losing badly, then what would happen if the Knicks started winning? A few people, specifically fans and former players, took it upon themselves to give a few suggestions to the Knickerbockers franchise main proprietor James Dolan.

While Jackson’s indirect taunting of All-Star forward Carmelo has earned him some ire, it hasn’t completely killed his cult. Early last year Charles Oakley advised fans to trust Jackson. A year later these comments of good faith earned him no solace at Madison Square Garden as his long-standing feud with Dolan escalated to a point where Commissioner Adam Silver and Michael Jordan had to team-up like the Avengers in order to rectify the relationship. MJ, The Winningest of Winners, the Six Ring King, the man who has chased victory like Ahab chased Moby Dick, has seen some tough time as the Hornets owner, but if one of the most egomaniacal personalities in all of sports is playing peacekeeper something is horribly wrong. Furthermore, this instance that was just a point has happened again. Thus, making it a trend.

Before a home game against the Boston Celtics, Knicks fan Mike Hamersky stood outside of Madison Square Garden and decided to heckle a passing James Dolan. Hamersky has been watching the Knicks since he could remember and he had been attending games regularly as of six seasons ago. He found himself embittered by the Isiah Thomas years but hopeful with Porzingis at the forefront of the Knicks future. He decided to engage in a cathartic moment by taunting Dolan with a sly suggestion.

It didn’t work out the way he thought. According to Hamersky, the vengeful tirade managed to include the word “asshole,” work in an insinuation to alcoholism (again), and ordered MSG security to refuse Hamersky entry into the arena. A mere, “Sell the team, Jim!” invoked a wrath akin to a kid unaccustomed to trash talk lashing out.

He had an open bottle of beer and smelled of alcohol, and I told him he wasn’t going in — Dolan to Deadspin’s Dave McKenna

If the past few months have revealed anything, then it’s that a thick wallet still isn’t a good substitute for a thick skin. Someone who reacts that poorly when they’re losing makes it painfully obvious they’ve never seen the winner’s corner before. It’s peak sore losing. Furthermore, it’s indicative of the Knicks fractured relationship with fans.

Truthfully, it doesn’t feel good to be called out on you failures when the whole world sees them already. Part of Dolan’s monologue had a “woe is me” sentiment that affirmed the idea that he still hadn’t gotten used to criticism even after all these years.

“If owning the Knicks is this much of a joyless experience, then just cash out your billions and sell them team,” Hamersky said. Although he is perturbed by his Dolan encounter, Hamersky still plans on renewing his season tickets as early as this month. Thus, economically feeding the machine that tortures him every year; it is very much akin to the Cleveland Browns’ Factory of Sadness.

It has become apparent that fan malcontent matters little to those in control as long as pockets stay fat like Big Pun. The Knicks are the highest valued franchise, but they just ended their streak of most sold out games last month.

Granted, it was with an impending snow storm on the way, but I’d imagine “rain, shine, or hellfire” is always in effect if you’re a hardcore fan. Not meeting capacity isn’t much of a wake up call, but it remains to be seen if any fan reaction to mediocrity will be addressed positively. Alas, the Knicks aren’t alone in this waning fandom. Other teams have gone through it in recent years while some are actively coping with a failing team.

The Heat are a franchise that has been through a roller coaster for the last seven years. Being dubbed LeBron’s chosen team, then finding out about the Cavaliers signing via Sports Illustrated are sets of shocks that would irritate any fan base.

Popular tweeter and noted Miami Heat fan @RawanHoops weighed in on the happenings in the aftermath.

“I was angry because I felt like Miami gave LeBron everything and just because we didn’t win one year he just left,” she said. Simply put, LeBron’s decision was his own, and although finger pointing about who could have altered his decision is enticing, it didn’t solve the vacuum that James left for the franchise. Rawan believes the Heat media folks didn’t take it too well, either, but the franchise, as a professional face, were stoic in the face of adversity.

This nuanced approach to misfortune is foreign to the Knicks. In the wake of James’ return to Cleveland, Miami brass let cooler heads prevail. With better times behind them and potential in front of them, the leaders of the organization attempted a legitimate rebuild.

The dichotomy between the Knicks and Heat temperaments is staggering. Both had lottery picks in the 2015 NBA Draft, but the Heat were well on their way to building around a solid core of Whiteside, Justice Winslow, and even a re-emerging Dion Waiters. They’ve found themselves just out of reach of the playoffs while the Knicks impulsive decisions in the offseason have led them to another tank. The Knicks botched win-now response has alienated even more fans in spite of Kristaps Porzingis’ improving play. The Heat opted for growth, the Knicks reached for wins, and then the Miami Heat turned out better.

The Silver Linings Playbook for New York’s Losing Season
Let’s look at what gets Knicks fans out of bed during this dismal seasontheknickswall.com

Rawan does confess that the biggest qualm with management was the mishandling of Dwyane Wade.

“He was all we really grew up on. This generation at least. They should have treated him better. The whole situation was messed up,” she said. The former Heat hero signed with the Chicago Bulls after contract talks fell apart, in lieu the front office brandish of a flourishing Waiters. They lost one of the greatest shooting guards of all time and replaced him with a struggling journeyman who was usually the butt of the joke. Nonetheless, he averaged 15 points with a 41.5 percent from three after the All-Star break (via ESPN).

Pat Riley hiccuped by giving up the most famous starter in lineup, then recovered by picking up Waiters on a rookie level contract. The Knicks traded a way Robin Lopez and overpaid for a chronically disappointing Joakim Noah. Phil Jackson wanted a defensive anchor, but had to settle for a financial burden. In short, the Heat have done well, and the Knicks haven’t, but a little luck played a part in keeping fans interested with consistently winning basketball.

It’s easy to compare such a positive case, but the Knicks might have a kindred spirit with a division rival. The Philadelphia 76ers have been in a perpetual state of rebuilding, but with Joel Embiid, aka The Process, coming along (when healthy) the fans have something to look forward to. However, the road to success is still a bit rocky.

Kyle Neubeck, the managing editor of SB Nation’s Liberty Ballers added some perspective. The 76ers organization has angered fans by their approach, or rather they have distracted them with players’ injuries. This has been a fairly consistent failing on the 76ers part, and is one criticism the diverse set of fans can usually agree on.

People around here can tolerate losing, but I don’t think anyone likes to be lied to or misled by the franchise they invest their time in — Kyle Neubeck

The Knicks mimicked this by supplying misinformation on multiple occasions this year, however, none of them were on the court. For example, the Charles Oakley situation where Dolan implied the former Knicks was an alcoholic with a tendency to abuse both physically and verbally. Or, when Dolan’s only response to a query about the team’s mediocre play was, “Ask Phil.” Inconsistent communication? 76ers — Check. Knicks — Check.

James Dolan Is A Big, Fat Phony
In a publicity stunt to save his image, the Knicks owner brought back a different lost Knickerbockertheknickswall.com

Neubeck remarked that since Sam Hinkie’s method of management had begun to produce fruit, fans in general have been a bit more optimistic, while others are still a bit uncomfortable about the team milking his succeeding strategy after his firing.

“I think this is a smart fan base that can get behind a coherent vision if management brings one to the table. There’s been plenty of that lately,’’ Neubeck disclosed. A fully thought out plan is much easier to get behind than a championship run that crashed and burned into a tank within two months. Coherent Plan? 76ers — Check. Knicks — Nah.

The 76ers have a fairly new President of Basketball Operations like the Knicks as well. Bryan Colangelo, son of the preceding president, Jerry Colangelo, has felt the brunt of reproach for his lackluster handling of the Nerlens Noel trade.

“His trade record leaves a lot to be desired…and there’s a growing sense of mistrust for how he’s going to shape the team outside of the draft,” Nuebeck expressed. This is a mirror image of Jackson’s assessed abilities. His drafting of Porzingis and Willy Hernangómez have been the only true bright spots of his tenure. The now defunct Derrick Rose is injured, and probably won’t (read: shouldn’t) return. Robin Lopez’s solid contract was replaced with the dead weight of Noah’s $72 million payday. Good draft, bad trades? 76ers — Check. Knicks — Check.

Neubeck elaborated on how culture plays a part in organizations and how even though the 76ers have gone through their dark ages, the people who work throughout the organization have good reputations. After all, the cogs in a clock are what make it run.

For as bad as they’ve been prior to this year, the guys who have played here and worked with the staff generally speak highly of the coaches and a lot of the different arms of the franchise…taking steps to be a first-class organization is something you can control.

The corporate culture, or even just the culture of the organization as an entity, is an important element to any group of people hoping to achieve greatness. Jackson’s inability to respect Anthony through direct communication has been a glaring offense through most of the season. Any setting where adults must interact negligence by way of professionalism is a shameful transgression.

Although head coach Jeff Hornacek has looked to appease his bosses by agreeing to run the Triangle Offense for the foreseeable future, it hasn’t done much but secured his job for half a season longer. A bit of resistance on his part might have earned him more confidence in the locker room, or, it might just earn him a trip to the unemployment line quicker than if he didn’t push back. This might just be another chip stacked against them, but the list is getting pretty high.

The Knicks best shot at salvaging this season is obtaining a lottery pick in this summer’s draft that happens to be flush with point guards. Jackson may have the people’s confidence to choose well, but fans don’t want him around for anything else. His game is pretty one-dimensional. If Knicks owner James Dolan hopes to repair the team’s relationship with fans (he probably doesn’t care unless it disturbs his day), then he’d better hire someone from outside the company because the organization looks toxic.

Despite the Knicks embarrassing failures, they’ll undoubtedly still fill seats with disenchanted fans whose hearts can take breaking at least one more time. Thus, paying for an inferior product they loathe. Hamersky, anxiously waiting to renew his season tickets, summed up this vicious cycle in a few glum, defeated words.

“It’s clear that nothing can keep me away from the Knicks.”

— Ty Jordan, site writer
